A past participle is a word that indicates

Some are easy.

With regular verbs they're exactly the same;

So: "see" becomes not "saw", but "seen".

A rule for modals are: When you... is when

form of the verb.
Right?

So, an example: "I can do it", "You could

I'll say: "We will do something", "We will...

So, the verb that follows a modal has to be
in the base form, versus the verb that follows
the verb "have", which is a past participle.

This is the base form.

At the end of the sentence, you cannot use
a contraction, as the whole verb is stressed.
You might be saying: "What does that mean?"

Well, when you're at the end of a sentence,
for example, this: "I am", you can't use a
contraction to say: "I'm".

And if you don't understand why, listen to

-"Are you going to the party?"

So, this contraction makes us think there's
